question_text: What is the role of the critical turbulent Karlovitz number (Kac) in distinguishing the pre-transition and post-transition regimes of monotonic MIE transition?
standard_answer: The critical turbulent Karlovitz number (Kac) demarcates the boundary between pre-transition and post-transition regimes in monotonic MIE transition. Kac is defined as the ratio of turbulent strain rate to characteristic reaction rate, representing the intensity of turbulence-chemistry interaction. In the pre-transition regime (Ka < Kac), turbulent eddies are larger than the reaction zone thickness, and the flame kernel develops similarly to laminar conditions with gradual MIET increase. The reaction zone remains intact, and flame propagation exhibits thin, wrinkled fronts. In the post-transition regime (Ka > Kac), turbulent eddies penetrate the reaction zone, causing local extinction, increased heat loss, and disrupted kernel development. This leads to distributed combustion with broken flamelets and exponential MIET rise. For methane-air mixtures, Kac ranges from 8 to 26 depending on equivalence ratio, with minimum near stoichiometric conditions due to optimal reaction rates.

original_text.1: In the pre-transition when Ka < Kac, MIET increases gradually with increasing Ka, flame kernel formation is similar to that of laminar spark ignition, and 2D laser tomography images of subsequent outwardly-propagating turbulent flames show sharp fronts (thin reaction zone) [61].
original_text.2: On the other hand, in the post-transition when Ka > Kac, MIET increases abruptly with increasing Ka, flame kernel is disrupted, turbulent flames reveal and subsequent randomly-propagating distributed-like fronts with islands and/or broken flame kernels [61,64,67].
